title: A deleterious Na<sub>v</sub>1.1 mutation selectively impairs telencephalic inhibitory neurons derived from Dravet Syndrome patients
abstract: Dravet Syndrome is an intractable form of childhood epilepsy associated with deleterious mutations in <italic>SCN1A</italic>, the gene encoding neuronal sodium channel Na<sub>v</sub>1.1. Earlier studies using human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have produced mixed results regarding the importance of Na<sub>v</sub>1.1 in human inhibitory versus excitatory neurons. We studied a Na<sub>v</sub>1.1 mutation (p.S1328P) identified in a pair of twins with Dravet Syndrome and generated iPSC-derived neurons from these patients. Characterization of the mutant channel revealed a decrease in current amplitude and hypersensitivity to steady-state inactivation. We then differentiated Dravet-Syndrome and control iPSCs into telencephalic excitatory neurons or medial ganglionic eminence (MGE)-like inhibitory neurons. Dravet inhibitory neurons showed deficits in sodium currents and action potential firing, which were rescued by a Na<sub>v</sub>1.1 transgene, whereas Dravet excitatory neurons were normal. Our study identifies biophysical impairments underlying a deleterious Na<sub>v</sub>1.1 mutation and supports the hypothesis that Dravet Syndrome arises from defective inhibitory neurons.
